ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Creative thinking (not only related to screens!), Japanese history, all sorts of Japanese artifacts, general art concepts.

I gained immense knowledge of the function and motifs of japanese screens, as well as how to analyze an image in multiple ways. I learned about the history, and how screens can be religious, political, or merely conversation starters.
Learned a lot about byobu and all types of Japanese art.

This class offers a foundational knowledge of Japanese screen painting, its history, its painters, and its theory. Discussions focus on screen paintings but alto the spatial and and social implications of the screen itself.
engaging with screens and thinking critically and creatively about Japanese culture, painting and architecture
I learned about the history of Japanese screens and how to approach analyzing and writing about these screens through a critical/artistic lens.
Both a lot of subject specific knowledge on byobu/Japanese folding screens, but also a lot of larger more philosophical and theoretical discussions of art and art history.

I gained an exposure to Japanese screens (and culture). Each session was based around a different theme related to a screen or pair of screens, so it was a cool thematic learning experience rather than being too linear.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Mimi is easily one of the best professors I have had at Yale. So caring, so understanding, and so knowledgable! Also, you have access to the Yale art gallery to study screens with one of the world leading experts, it's just such a cool experience! Literally, no weaknesses. Perfect class.
Loved that we could see screens in person. I also liked the relaxed assignments, because they didn't put too much stress on workload overall.
Very interesting course material and not too much workload.
Strengths: Amazing professor, getting to see Japanese screens in person, fun material. No weaknesses!

Strengths: The professor Mimi, the object-based learning style, interesting content. Also loved the structure--rather than longer essays, we had shorter "Brief Notes" due throughout the semester, which were open-ended and allowed us to pursue whatever areas of interests related to the course's content that we wanted. 
Weaknesses: the classes could feel long and hard to get through, but that is difficult to avoid with a 2-hour 9am. We always had a short break in the middle, which helped.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, please, take this class. Even if you are just a little bit interested in art, you will love this class, and you don't need any previous knowledge in the matter. If you can't take this class, then definitely take one with Mimi. Everyone at Yale should!

Most definitely!! Professor Yiengpruksawan is extremely knowledgable and engaging, asking us tough questions and giving insight into how screens were used and viewed. I really enjoyed the beauty of screens, and also that there is such a unique topic to explore Asian art.
Yes, definitely, especially if you would like to learn more about Japanese art.
Yes! This is a fantastic class for anyone looking to engage with eastern art. The course also offere the rare experience to frequently engage with YUAG materials.
Yes definitely! regardless of your major, this class would be super inspiring
Yes! Really interesting course taught by a passionate professor!
Yes, its a great class with an excellent professor.
Yes, I would! The professor is wonderful and cares a lot about her students, and the content is a great introduction to Japanese art and culture if you haven't studied it before.
